instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01041: What is 820-01041? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PP2V5_NAND_SSD0: What is PP2V5_NAND_SSD0? PP2V5_NAND_SSD0 This is a power rail that powers the NAND on Macbooks where the solid state drive is soldered directly to the board. .
definitions.PP2V5_NAND_SSD1: What is PP2V5_NAND_SSD1? PP2V5_NAND_SSD1 is a power rail that powers the soldered on SSDs.
definitions.PP1V8_SSD0: What is PP1V8_SSD0? PP1V8_SSD0 is a power rail responsible for powering the soldered on NAND memory for the SSD on newer Macbook Pros.
definitions.PP0V9_SSD0: What is PP0V9_SSD0? This is a power rail for the soldered on SSD on newer Macbooks. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0.06a and unable to restore T2
threads.message:
Clean board, someone already tried to mess with it and <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> looked like it was removed the put back, clean other than that.

Restoring in both Catalina and Big Sur give same error, the software hangs for ever and cannot restore T2

Measuring NAND voltages the only weird measurement is <SIGNAL>P0V9_LX0_SSD1</SIGNAL> at 0.6V while <SIGNAL>P0V9_LX0_SSD0</SIGNAL> is fine at 0.9V, <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SSD0</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SSD1</SIGNAL> are fine at 1.8V and <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD1</SIGNAL> is fine at 2.5V.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0.06a and unable to restore T2
threads.message:
Compare diode mode to ground on L9020/520.
Better if you have similar good board for reference.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0.06a and unable to restore T2
threads.message:
L9020 is 0.345 and L9520 is 0.415

I don't have another one of this boards to compare unfortunately.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0.06a and unable to restore T2
threads.message: If there is something else I should try please advice.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0.06a and unable to restore T2
threads.message:
If machine is detected in DFU, but cannot complete the process, very likely SSD problem.
More than probable in your case, as you already have a bad SSD voltage.
Of course, can be T2 itself with internal damage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0.06a and unable to restore T2
threads.message: This may be a silly thing to say, but can that side of the SSD on the board be disable so it only uses either 256Gb or 512Gb instead of 1Tb? The problem on this board is with <SIGNAL>P0V9_LX0_SSD1</SIGNAL> while  <SIGNAL>P0V9_LX0_SSD0</SIGNAL> is fine.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0.06a and unable to restore T2
threads.message: Okay if I inject 0.9V from the PS into <SIGNAL>P0V9_LX0_SSD1</SIGNAL> the computer boots up and works, any tips on how to take this voltage from somewhere else on the board to make it a permanent solution will be greatly appreciated, I tried a few dumb options but had no luck.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0.06a and unable to restore T2
threads.message:
You should change <CHIP>U9500</CHIP>.
I don't think to be a good idea to pick <SIGNAL>PP0V9_SSD0</SIGNAL> from <CHIP>U9000</CHIP> side (leaving out L9520/21); overload may kill it.

You can try with a small buck converter to get it from <SIGNAL>3V3_G3H_SSD1</SIGNAL>.
[URL unfurl="true"]https://www.aliexpress.com/item/4000016331112.html?acnt=439-079-4345&aff_platform=aaf&ds_e_device=c&albcp=11505901136&ds_e_product_id=es4000016331112&ds_url_v=2&ds_dest_url=https%3A%2F%2Fs.click.aliexpress.com%2Fdeep_link.htm%3Faff_short_key%3DUneMJZVf&ds_e_product_group_id=743612850874&pvid=20fbff0d-412b-46e6-8a38-4ac6fab536c9&sk=UneMJZVf&scm=1007.23534.124736.0&ds_e_adid=476171223963&terminal_id=e4347aedefcf4e24a74f4da43544eb86&needSmbHouyi=false&albbt=Google_7_shopping&ds_e_product_channel=online&src=google&ds_e_product_country=ES&aff_fcid=c4d7fda1bb3c4e92ac144d47b117cdfe-1620198970055-01274-UneMJZVf&gclid=CjwKCAjwhMmEBhBwEiwAXwFoETPM-ELGfimEUh7iiQixCHoUGiOu_a3zx2BDt31rFXqi1TSfofAQixoCQgYQAvD_BwE&albag=115252975111&aff_fsk=UneMJZVf&albch=shopping&ds_e_network=u&albagn=888888&ds_e_product_language=es&isSmbAutoCall=false&ds_e_product_merchant_id=107689561&aff_trace_key=c4d7fda1bb3c4e92ac144d47b117cdfe-1620198970055-01274-UneMJZVf&rmsg=do_not_replacement&gclsrc=aw.ds[/URL]
You may need to find one to work with 3V3 input; the above one accept 4.5V, is just an example.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01041</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 20v 0.06a and unable to restore T2
threads.message: Thanks, I just ordered the chips from China, I hope with just the chip the MacBook will work, otherwise I have looked at the step down converter and the closest one I found is  [URL='https://www.ebay.com/itm/132416728307?epid=22010594256&hash=item1ed4a6ecf3:g:9jAAAOSwxR1dyOfr']this one[/URL] the only problem is that the minimum input is 4.5V the output can be adjusted, will it work you think?
